Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Personalization Platform to Enhance Third-Party Children's Content and Improve School Readiness
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase II project addresses the issue that while mobile devices hold great promise for education, most of the kids' apps that claim to be educational ultimately amount to little more than brain candy. Furthermore, the few apps that are based on educational research are resource-intensive to develop and therefore have limited opportunity to scale their success. This project is building an educational platform that addresses the problems of both quality and scale in this market. It is creating a content enhancement system designed specifically for creating research-based educational content that allows developers and content studios to build mobile and web apps at a fraction (10%-20%) of the cost of traditional app development. The content built using this system is automatically integrated with analytics and personalization technology that tailors the content to each child based on the child's responses. The personalization technology applies methods from psychometrics and cognitive development to ensure that the content adapts to the child and facilitates learning in an engaging way. The project will deliver a large library of context-based and personalized learning content for preK and primary grades that parents know is based on sound research, and ultimately helps increase school readiness and learning outcomes. Given the growing demand for age-appropriate mobile educational content for children, this project has the potential to generate significant returns as a commercial enterprise and, importantly, through the economic gains resulting from improvements in educational outcomes. It will also give content developers the opportunity to economically develop and deploy new content that uses personalization technology, without having to build this complex technology themselves, thereby applying this innovation at a large scale.

This SBIR Phase II project is building a mobile game-based learning platform to onboard high quality third-party children's educational content and enhance their effectiveness through analytics and personalization. To achieve this, the project is developing two significant technical innovations: (1) a cloud-based personalization engine that powers adaptive learning in varied educational contexts and (2) a content enhancement system to efficiently and economically enrich third-party children's content (in the form of digital assets, books, or videos) with interactive learning games that are powered by the personalization logic. The personalization engine will use machine learning techniques combined with statistical methods of psychometric assessment and principles from cognitive development. It will inconspicuously measure children's interaction with the proposed platform's educational content and dynamically adjust game-play to suit each user's individual skills, interests and educational needs. The proposed model of leveraging and augmenting the efforts of many content developers is a dramatic departure from existing content development paradigms in this space. The goal of the project is to substantially increase the scale and reach of personalized, research-based learning experiences on mobile devices and ultimately maximize the potential of modern technology to deliver dynamic learning experiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the life of the project SmartyPal created a software suite that uses educational content to create interactive or game-based experiences that collect data about the knowledge of users and adapts the experience based on their prior interactions with the software (Figure 1).  This suite includes four major parts: 1) a Unity-based template system for creating cross-platform interactive content and mini-games at a fraction of the cost of building standalone interactive content; 2) a system of customizable SmartGames that enable customers’ to incorporate content into fully functional mobile-style games (Figure 2); 3) a web portal for teachers and managers to see how users are performing on their content (Figure 3); and 4) a cloud-based Adaptive Learning Engine.  That engine integrates with our interactive content, SmartGames, and portal to modify the experience for individual users, ensure the relevance and efficacy of the presented content, and provide data insights.

The Unity-based template system is useful to academic publishers and corporate partners with large libraries of static, boring content that can benefit from being transformed into interactive experiences.  For example, in a proof-of-concept we did for an academic publisher, we created a mini-game for a book on bats in which the user had to find food using the principle of echolocation. The game, which would have required extended development without our template system, was created by a single designer in a matter of a couple of days using art assets clipped from the book and a navigation template originally created for controlling a spaceship in our “My Space Adventure” app.

Our SmartGames take the template system a step farther, creating fully functional and tested games which users can insert their questions and content into.  These games do not offer the same level of customizability as the template system, but users’ content is easily uploaded with no need to plan, design, or modify any of the interactive aspects of the technology.  Students and employees can be granted access to all of the advantages of games and gamification, and teachers and managers gain access to data-based insights about what learners know, without needing to make expensive investments in one-off games and the data back-end needed for adaptive learning, data collection, and the analytic insights presented via a web portal.

Our Adaptive Learning Engine powers a recommender system which monitors how users are performing on content and what content they interact with to suggest what they should learn.  We have developed a system of algorithms to adjust what is shown. This system can increase the difficulty level of the content when users revisit an activity. It can also monitor performance on specific topics so that the system learns what a user is good at and can suggest topics to users that they need the most help with.  The algorithms for the SmartGames now also includes a Lietner Box system which uses a combination of performance and the time since a user has interacted with content to space out how often content is shown and to periodically revisit content to ensure that performance is still high on content that was previously mastered. These systems are all aimed at making the learning process more efficient by ensuring content is of the appropriate difficulty level, regularly monitoring performance so that attention is directed toward relevant content that a user needs to learn, spacing learning so that true retention is maximized and users are not just memorizing information to pass a test (Figure 4), and by making the learning context more active and engaging so that it holds users’ attention and maximizes their learning.

These technologies have functionality that can be useful to publishers and companies that serve learning and development functions for corporations.  Our systems not only offer a savings of time and money in generating learning content, but they incorporate data functionality and adaptivity that is cost prohibitive for individual companies to build as they fulfill their content needs and try to reach learning goals.  As more of the major traditional book publishers figure out the emerging digital market and how to profit from that market, we expect the level of interest in our template system and data back-end to continue to increase.

Finally, we have started to explore uses of this technology for creating activities that work in a classroom to structure a curriculum and make in-class learning more engaging.  To do that we started an after school program called KidsMakeItRight, with our first project and curriculum focused on reducing trash and increasing recycling. As we explore how to support mentors (i.e., teachers) in offering a more enriching after school experience, we will learn both about how best to use our technology to support classroom learning and test whether after school programs offer a legitimate business opportunity.
